ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned elementary German grammar and culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
This class was definitely a mixed bag. Some of the strengths of the class were the immersion aspect, which definitely strengthened my German writing and speaking skills. I also appreciated that the class was not as focused on test taking, and structured assessments in a way that made them feel low-stress.  Constantin was also very helpful in explaining some of the tricky aspects of German grammar. I also appreciated the flexibility with deadlines, and found that the instructors were generally very passionate about their work. 

That being said, the class is entirely too much work. I would have appreciated if the class took a "less is more" approach, as the sheer amount of work assigned made it nearly impossible to keep up with what was going on. The asynchronous Wednesdays often took more than fifty minutes. I also received nearly no detailed feedback on my homework, which was delivered weeks after assignments were turned in. Grading often felt slightly harsh in a class where mistakes were supposed to be welcome.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to another student who is passionate about the subject. My German skills definitely improved... but at what cost. I would discourage anyone taking over five credits from taking the class, as keeping up with the material felt nearly impossible.
